reviewText:
If I were reviwing only the game, I would not hesitate to give it 4 stars. The large open world with countless ports to explore and trade at, the many types of ship to sail, and the deep storyline blending historical accuracy with fantasy is very well done. This is no surprise coming from KOEI who are well known for their deep simulations and stories.

The graphics, while dated, serve the game well and each port has a recognizable flavor to it. With many job titles across three archetypes (adventure, trade, and combat) and skill trees for all three, players have great flexibility in how to customize their characters to suit their own playstyle. Many games make this claim, UWO is one of the few to actually back it up with ample content for all career paths, and the game experience does not culminate in endless repetetive pvp. I would give four stars, not five, witholding one for some unclear writing and a cumbersome system for helping others with quests.

The playerbase in my experience has been mature, polite and helpful, and the premium content shop is not game breaking. This is not a pay to win game.

However, the inclusion of Nprotect GameGuard singlehandedly trumps any and all good points of the actual game (and there are many!) Gameguard advertises itself as an anti-cheat software, but installs itself as a rootkit. You are required to disable any antivirus software, because  gameguard behaves exactly as a virus. This leaves you with no protection while playing an online game, and is unacceptable from a security and common sense view. Even if it worked as intended, this would be unacceptable, but looking over the complaints on the forum make it clear this software does far too much harm, and any claims of it doing any good ar eimpossible to prove. Is the game free of cheaters because of gameguard? Or is it free of cheaters because it is an old game with dated graphics and requires  a reasonable intelligence and attention span to play? Finally, uninstalling the game will NOT remove gameguard, this requires manual removal, instructions can be found via google.

Pros:
Decent graphics, music and atmosphere.
Rich world, dialogue and flavor text, quests have actual storylines to them.
Actual content for all play styles, not merely a pvp funnel.
Long voyages actually feel like long voyages (This can be good or bad)
A freemium game that is NOT pay to win!

Cons:
Unable to walk around your ship
Installs rootkit on your computer.
Customer support has been all but abandoned.

Bottom line: If it ever removes the rootkit, its absolutely worth playing. Until then, avoid like the plague.

reviewText:
I have a lot to say but keep in mind it's from the perspective of a solo PVE player that has seen far from everything. I'll get right down to what I like and don't like.

Pros:

- The three classes (adventurer, soldier, trader) are distinct, with their own unique abilities. Further, the subclasses (jobs) that you can choose from promote skills, which encourages finding your niche and working on it. This makes for a good sense of progression, character uniqueness and a broad selection of playstyles. For combat there is naval and land, ranged and melee; and adventurers have a range of playstyles, from collecting data around the world, to hunting down shipwrecks, and going on long voyages to make discoveries. Apart from freeform gameplay, there are also semi-randomised quests.

-  The world is vast and there's a lot to see. You won't see all the content for hundreds of hours of gameplay. It's not derivative, either - it's awesome when you unlock a new part of the world to explore.

- So many different ways to play. There's something for everyone. Adventuring is about long voyages, discoveries and treasure-hunting; maritime and land battles have some options and depth to them; trading is for more patient money-hoarding players with good knowledge of the trade lanes and goods, as well as inventory management.

- Plenty of depth in the gameplay, you're always learning more tricks of the trade such as which consumables you're going to need to combat events at sea, or you can pick up skills to do that, or even set an aide to do it for you if they have the appropriate skills. You have many options in character-building and higher levels open up more possibilities.

Cons:

- The grind. Yeah, getting to the ''endgame'' (top-of-the-line ship and most advanced class) will take many, many hours. Although in this case, it's more about the journey than the destination. This isn't the type of game where you have to be endgame to get access to the worthwhile content.

- The tutorials take hours. Seriously, you're looking at 10+ hours to get through all the schools. You don't have to, and you can go your own way at any time and come back later. Still, they are worth doing for the rewards despite the backtracking and awkward dialogue.

- Documentation is poor. A lot of things in the game are not self-explanatory, and you won't find written help ingame. I've played for dozens of hours and I still couldn't tell you all the differences between Recog, Search and Observe skills. The good news is, it's not necessary to know every game mechanic. You pick whatever playstyle you want and you learn as you go. Also, the ingame community is very friendly and helpful.

- Pay2Win elements. I'm not all that qualified to explain this since I don't play competitively, but there is at least one item that gives you an advantage over other players in the open seas (which are pvp zones): 30% speed boosters. That's huge, and I suspect it can be used to allow even the most sluggish pirate to hunt down even the speedist newb player. Sounds like a doozy. Thankfully, you can chart a course that takes you far from the major sealanes and the coast, for a good chance of avoing player pirates. Still, items like that are disconcerting. Also, buying a monthly subscription (about 15 dollars. Or Euros... hm...) gives you a fat paycheck in ingame currency. I don't know whether to put this under pay2win or not, but I guess if you're seeking pvp, yeah it would allow the subscribed player to get expensive gear sooner.

So in my experience, UWO is great if you're after a PVE experience with a Renaissance maritime flavor. I know you don't get many options for that rubric, but it's good. I can't vouch for the pvp however, and you should be prepared for a long (if not steep) learning curve.

reviewText:
UWO is a game that has a lot of depth but takes up a lot of time, so if you do not have the time, do not read further.

Uncharted Waters Online is a fairly old MMO that has been out for a while. I personally played it intensively for a year (when it was under Netmarble and when it was exclusively available on the OGP launcher) before I had to quit due to real life commitments. It is a great game that has a lot of depth due to complex mechanics and the reliance on knowing a lot of things if you want to do it the best way. However, the complexity and the gruelling tutorial system (that feels like real-like work) keep potential players away. Please, I urge you to try to get past it and see the game from an intermediate player's point of view. I know that I initially thought the game was boring during school but grew on me once I kept on playing.

If you are looking for a great trading experience online while interacting with others, you are right at home! Even from the beginning, you are introduced to a commodity system similar to stocks (like in Port Royale) with lots of numbers. You can start fresh, trading between Dover and London and etc then eventually work your way to a long-distance Nanban trading routes such as Nagasaki (Japan) <-> London (England). Watching your character grow and your coffers fill up with money is the most satisfying thing in this game. I could say a thousand things about this but you will have to see for yourself. Be warned though, this does take a lot of real-life time so be wary of real life commitments.

The combat is great but I have to admit that it is getting aged. The most amount of satisfaction you will get from the combat is beating other players rather than the combat system being great in of itself. It is a basic system of control your ship, choose ammo, and sink/board the enemy ship. I always found the system to be secondary to trade and more important towards the late-game for Epic Sea Feuds (massive player naval combat battle events), pirate hunting, etc. The bottom line is, it is great but don't have too high expectations. It is great FOR ITS TIME.

It has a ton of neat features you wouldn’t see in many modern MMOs. Want a customizable apartment with a steward? Done. Want to have cool ships that you saw in those pirate books or movies that you dreamed of? You’re right at home. Want a companion character that helps you perform your job (trading, crafting, pirating, or whatever it may be) and can be dressed up/renamed for your every little fetishes? Done deal. Where have you seen a game with literally over a hundred cities and the world size that takes you half of real-life to go around? It is truly a gem that needs to be appreciated more.

The community for the most part is very dedicated and friendly. If you can meet their expectations and be dedicated yourself, they will love you and you will love them. If you are looking for a great experience playing a slow-paced MMO you can sink your time into and make a lot of long-term friends, you will like UWO. However, if you are looking for a more faster paced MMO with emphasis on action-packed PvP and PvE raiding combat, you may want to look at a more modern MMO. This is an old-school MMO that does not hold your hand and it is up to you to stand up on your feet and reach up to it.

tl;dr

This game is good, give it a try.
Be warned that it is a time vampire.

Say goodbye to the outside.

I've played this game on and off for a few years now and am glad it's come to Steam, if a bit late. Comparing it to other mmorpgs, I'd say the difficulty level is a little more challenging than most. KOEI is known for making historically accurate games and this one is no exception. While it was released to asian markets only for the first several years, it has been available for the rest of the world for the past several. It's as old as Word of Warcraft, but is free-to-play. Also something to note, it is *not* pay-to-win, like some f2p games are. Some of the best items/ships are potentially/statistically superior, it isn't such a noticable difference, unless in the hands of an unskilled/inexperienced player. And there are a LOT of ships to suit your playstyle.

Concerning playstyles, there are 3 major ways to play the game, and you can change it up as you see fit without too much hassle. Adventuring, Trading, and Battling. Adventurers have probably the closest to a single-player experience as you can get on an mmo, and won't be disappointed with the historical discoveries, locations and treasures that come from diligence. Trading is probably one of the easiest tasks, and is practiced by every player-type. Many different trade goods from various regions of the world and a very deep economic structure that changes prices of goods depending on supply/demand and trading tendencies of other players. Maritime (sea battles) is one of the more appealing features to newcomers and seasoned players alike, and UWO has probably the best sea-battle gameplay around.

PVP exists in the majority of sea zones throughout the world but only the truly skilled maritimers can benefit from a life of piracy on the high seas. I've been pirated only a handful of times in the years I've played and it should be noted that it isn't something to deter you from going where you want to go. There is a healthy balance to all things.

As for the community of players, some of the nicest and most helpful players abound here! There are so many intricacies to the gameplay, I still learn something new daily, and nearly everyone has an answer or an idea to help you along. We're really all in it together! -A trader does not JUST trade, they also craft non-purchaseable master level items that players can use. For example: extremely powerful hulls, extremely powerful cannons, and extremely good sails. The majority of the in-game economy revolves around these items.

-Finally, the adventurer. The adventurer does not have any actual purpose in PvP or money making, as it is out done by the fighter and trader respectively. *HOWEVER* The adventurer has the *FASTEST* ships, and discovering and doing adventure quests can be extremely fun if you have the patience, Albeit as tedious as the other 2 classes with less rewards.

I've been a huge fan of Koei's games since way back in the SNES / Super Famicom days.  Though I haven't played this one through steam, I have logged over 1k hours on and off over the last few years.

This game at it's core really is a good adaptation of the Uncharted Waters series into an MMO. The original version, launched in Japan in 2005 as a subscription based game,  looks like it's close to what I would consider an ideal MMO for a simulation junkie.  And that is what makes the version published here in the west such a bitter disapointment.  The after market cash shop they tacked on cheapens every aspect of the game.  It turns what was designed to be a repetitive but rewarding experience into an all out slog, a slog that spending 50 USD per month barely mitigates.  Many systems have been nerfed or slowed down from the original design in order to coerce players into whipping out a credit card to speed them back up.  The game is set up to have an incredibly robust player economy where all the best ships and items are crafted by players.  Top tier items in this version come only from the cash shop. Powerful ships better than anything a player can make come only from their lottery box. Certain recipes are cut from the crafting proffesions entirely so the items they make can be sold for cash.  Most of these items are tradable in game, but the fact that players can not make them on their own ruins most of the charm and intent of the design.

It is possible to get somewhere that resembles end game" without forking over a fortune

I would have to say that I quite enjoy this game. Its Eve Online meets the high seas without the spreadsheet BS.

[GRAPHICS] -The game graphics are itself dated but considering it was released a long time a go and only became available to Americans/Europeans somewhat more recently ( a few years ago). The character and city graphics are gawdy but are acceptable as you will be on the high seas and the ship details/water is where its at.

[SOUND/MUSIC] - The music isn't half bad and can be quite refreshing at first. It will change as you enter different territories/cities. It will become annoying after awhile if your constantly in one city or nation due to it being your home/ doing school quests. The ship sounds, (disaster, bell, etc) on the sea are a real nice touch as you travel.

[ENGINE] - This game is reaaaally easy to run as its an older engine. So anything can pretty much run it.

[GAMEPLAY] - This is where this game shines!, You can choose to either be a  trader, Adventurer, or Maritime ( <-- pirate basically ). You can trade goods for profit from one region to another, invest in towns to get your hands on unique goods, Find shipwrecks and bring them to the surface for a chance at getting very good loot to keep or sell. You can choose to be maritime, to either support your nation in wars, or ambush other players across the high seas to steal there cargo. While doing all this, you have to deal with giving your crew food/water, dealing with fatigue levels, etc. The dynamics of those 3 classes really flourish once you have joined an active company  or bought yourself a home to store goods. The game becomes soo much better after you push through the schools ( which do provide some useful info for beginners)

4/5 - The game itself can be quite addicting once your past all of the school quests. Some of the school quests are crap, others provide some basic/useful information to keeping you or your crew alive while on the seas. Each school provides money/ships/port permits once completing everything.  The gameplay becomes the core reason players who have endured the tutorial keep playing, so I suggest giving it a thorough try. I give it a 4/5 simply for the graphics being a bit dated ( which cant be helped), and some of the tutorial quests being bland and a bit pointless.

The highest end stuff is of course paid for with real money, but you don't need it to be successful. Another reason I'm still playing the game after two weeks.

reviewText:
Greetings, fellow gamers!

Admittedly, I've stepped away from UWO for a bit, but I will say that when I am engaged...I am ENGAGED!  This game is not for the time constrained for faint of heart.  As a fan of the Koei NES versions of the game: UW and UW2, this is an excellent successor to the series.

Gamer population: very helpful, with several differtent chats to choose from to seek guidance and help.  Several wiki's are available to support new gamers, or gamers that have fallen off the wagon.

Personalization: one of the best aspects of this game is the ability to personalize your toon and your ship.  Want to look like certain captain from a movie/cartoon, you can!  Want to make your ship resemble historical pirate ships? Find the paint and sail and it's yours!

Community content and indie adventures: Another plus.  The Game provides historical events the community and PC can participate in, which influence the game world, as well in-game non-aligned quests from quest hubs at the ports.  Random events and pirate attacks keep you on your toes as you negotiate the game mechanics.

Not so good: The tutorial is PAINFUL. Long and cumbersome, but necessary, if you want to know how to do the basics.  With the availability of the wikis and the willingness of the online community to share, the burden on the player is somewhat removed.

Graphics: dated and cheesy, but it's Koei and I'm a bit sentimental, so I forgive it.  Others may not be so forgiving.

Combat: the one-on-one duels can be frustrating if you don't have the right weapon/armor/tool mix to counter your enemy during boarding actions.  The land quests are fun, but can be just as frustrating.

The gradual degeneration of your ships hit points: this is the most tedious aspect of the game for me.  I get a new ship,  and over the couse of voyages, encounter pirates, rival factions, storms and other randome phenomenon.  I can either fix myself or take to a pro in port.  Either way, the max HP level for my ship deteriorates.  I understand the historical truisms the game tries to maintain, but this one gets under my finger nails!

By and large, this is a fun game, with lots to explore and do.  I'd say give it a spin and be willing to invest at least 20 hours to truely get a feel for it.

Edit: Managed to get it working again (somehow), so I'm changing the review.

UWO is very different from your average MMO, in no small part due to the majority of the game revolving around sailing the world and exploring, trading, or both. Upon starting, you're asked to pick a starting job from 3 choices: Adventurer (exploration), Trader (mercantile) and Battle (soldier). Each job has it's own skill set, and you're able to change jobs as you progress, so you're not just tied down to the one you pick at the beginning.
Sailing itself is rather easy once you get the hang of it, which shouldn't take very long. The main threat when at sea is other players. Around the starting areas of Europe, you're relatively safe as long as you can deal with or avoid NPC pirates. But in other regions of the world, the titular uncharted waters, other vessles are free to attack you. Thankfully the world is a big place so encounters shouldn't be too often, plus you can group up with friends and have them help you out in a fight. Operating a merchant vessle and concerned about hostile ships? Bring along a soldier buddy to watch your back as you make trade runs.

Overall the game is very fun to play. Points lost for the use of GameGuard, but hopefully that shouldn't be too much of a problem for many players.

reviewText:
This is a classic never ending MMORPG. You start out in school learning the basics of sailing, trading and combat and can choose any career path you want Adventuring, Trading, Combat (PVE or PVP) or a combination of all.

Sounds good and for a while you'll enjoy it but then you find you've done everything you wanted to in a skill or field and have to move on to another skill or job or go insane with boredom, there is no point staying as an expert at something.

Adventuring has huge scope with many different things to do, but unfortunately you will end up doing the same quests, hunting the same relics and raising the same shipwrecks over and over and over again.

Trading is again fine at the start, if you choose to stay F2P you'll grind your way up the skills buying and selling everything you can for profit until you make it to East Asia to trade. Buy dirt cheap get back to eurpoe and sell items for a huge profit to NPC's or to other players for an even huger profit, but once you've done it a few dozen times its pales quickly.

Combat in the game comes in two types, land or sea. Land combat is possibly the worst you will see in any modern MMO or possibly any game ever made, it is unbelieveable bad. The sea combat is better with fully buildable and modable ships it can be fun but again the missions are extremely limited and just attacking random NPC's hour after hour is amazingly boring.

PVP Combat is the way most people go before quitting. You use the fortune you've amassed to buy a NC (cash shop real money) ship that has been modded with NC items go to a busy trading area (most areas in the game outside europe are PVP) and attack people in trading ships. They know you are coming so leave all ther money and good items in the bank leaving you just thier cargo to steal (you can't take thier ships or even items equipped on thier ships atm). The only problem is that thier cargo is bought in the area you are patrolling so is basically worthless unless you transport it yourself and your crew heavy combat ship uses all its cargo space for food to feed your sailors. So you sit there attacking people who don't fight back, mabye you like that kind of thing, I don't.

Crafting is around par with the average MMO, grind you way up different skills (cooking for instance) until you get to rank 10, you then need to take a specialised job in that skill to get your rank higher. If you change your job you keep any xp you have gained in the skill but it can only be used at rank 10 until you take a specialised job again. Irritating as hell.

The UI is abysmal. Every time the Devs add something to the game it is added to a drop down menu with no help or explanation as to what it is. The initial training in school is OK as long as you rmember it has been transated from Japanese by someone with poor english and there are huge errors, one instructor has his title translated three different ways, one above his head, one from his own mouth and one in the quest log. you haven't a clue whats going on. The mainline quests are even worse, you can be stuck in the middle of nowhere with no idea what to do next.

I'm making it sound bad, I know. I played UWO for a few years as something different to my normal kind of game (DDO, LOTRO, SWTOR) before getting bored. I went back and lasted a month before dropping it again. I'm 2 weeks back into it and again bored, it seems to have reached its limit for me.

If you are looking for a way to kill a couple of years without focus then try this. Almost everything in the game takes a LOOONG time so it can eat up empty days you have easily. The guides are all dreadful or translated from the games original Japanese release badly so you can spend hours trying to find even the simplest of information.

There are a few good things about the game but they aren't game based. Most of the people in the game are friendly, it seems to be an entry level MMO and many haven't honed thier trolling skills yet. As the game has no real direction setting yourself personal goals and hitting them is also good.

This is definately a pay-to-win game. OGP the people running it are money mad, you can buy anything and everything in the cash shop except accounts, look hard enough on the web and you can find them up for sale everywhere though. The account-email verification link is broken.

I'm sitting here writing this as the game is down, again, OGP have been getting DDOS attacks lately. Everything they have is currently offline, a few days after they took everything down to 'fix the problem'. Nothing written on the facebook page and in fact nothing anywhere.

OGP is definately a company where cash comes first, then thats it, no second or third. Players/customers have no input or say in anything.

So my verdict on the game is simple, if you have never played an MMO of this type before give it a go. You will like its MMO freedom and the other players. Then when you are stuck (about 15 minutes in) go to a grown up game of this type like EVE. No rules, no direction and even though its P2P (a monthly pack in UWO is around 4 times the cost of a month in EVE), have a good first month and you can legally use in game money to pay for the game.

If you have played MMO's of this type before then stay away, far away. It can suck you in as all games can and as you're a good player you can get over all the bad points but in two years time you'll find you've just wasted two years.

Go to EVE, it costs but a lot less than this will, believe me I remember my bills.

rant over.....

reviewText:
Right away you should know that this game is NOT for people who are impatient. It takes ages to get anything important done, and there is a LOT of grinding.
That may sound like a negative, but really, this game makes grinding fun in oddly satisfying ways.
You can choose from three main professions: adventurer, merchant or soldier (although you can do all three on the same character if you want, nothing's stopping you).
The tutorial is very long, but only because there are a LOT of mechanics to this game that you need to know about before you set sail onto the open ocean. The complexity of this game's mechanics may discourage players who don't want a game that requires them to think about 15 different things at once. If you want a simple, low-effort game, this isn't for you at all.
BUT if you are okay with that, what you'll get is an MMO with an absolutely enormous world to explore. Almost the entire Earth has been modelled in this game and unlocking/exploring the whole thing will take weeks, maybe even months out of your life that you'll likely never call wasted.
Bottom line pros and cons:

Pros:
-Choose from six countries to represent: England, The Netherlands, France, Spain, Portugal or Venice.
-An enormous game world to explore.
-Exploration isn't only rewarded, it's kind of the whole point.
-Absolute sandbox freedom straight from the start (although doing the tutorial is highly recommended).
-Supportive and helpful community always happy to offer advice.
-Fans of PVP can become pirates and hunt down defenceless merchant players in certain parts of the world.
-Interesting and well-paced story.
-Very educational. You'll learn a lot about history, geography, different types of ships and loads more.
-The soundtrack can be very catchy and is usually very fitting to the environment.

Cons:
-Very grindy. The grinding isn't as monotonous as it is in some games, but a lot of your playtime will be spent grinding.
-PVP is virtually unavoidable. Other players can attack you anywhere outside of Europe, and if you're not battle-oriented, you need to be on your toes at all times.
-The player-run economy in this game is broken. A lot of even the most basic player-made items can be incredibly expensive.
-Repairing damaged equipment and restoring a ship's maximum health can only be done using special items that are much harder to get than they should be considering how often you will need them.
-The graphics, even on the highest setting, aren't anything to write home about.

Overall, this game is very fun for fans of this style. This game will be appealing to those who like this sort of MMO. For those who want fast-paced games full of action, this probably isn't what you're looking for. But if you like games with large amounts of effort, thinking and detail that allow as much freedom as you want at a slow and comfortable pace, this game is definitely worth a try.
8/10.
